abstract.p: Florence Fabricant reports on changes in restaurant scene, including opening of A-Z and Rhone Bar in Manhattan (M)

block.p: Jacques Torres, the executive pastry chef at Le Cirque for nearly 12 years, will leave at the end of June to work on the wholesale chocolate factory he plans to open in Brooklyn. He hopes to sell his products to restaurants and to retail customers through a Web site and eventually a retail store. Patrice Caillot, who was at Le Cirque in Las Vegas, will replace him at Le Cirque 2000.

There's nothing simple about A-Z, which just opened at 21 West 17th Street. How about a third-floor open-air dining room with a greenhouse roof that can zip itself closed at the first raindrop? Or a 500-bottle wine list that has categories like ''earth'' and ''wind''? Even the name is a play on words: it's pronounced ah-ZEE, like the French word for Asia, to suggest the fusion food prepared by Patricia Yeo. It's a handsome place, with a ground floor lounge and a second-floor banquet space under that terrace-like dining room on top.

Two sommeliers, Vincent Seufert and Jeffrey Goldenstein, have turned their passion for the wines of the Rhone Valley into the Rhone Bar, 63 Gansevoort Street (Greenwich Street), opening tomorrow. They pour wines from 16 Rhone appellations, with food by Payson Dennis.

Jasper White, the Boston chef who closed his eponymous restaurant five years ago and became a consultant, has just opened Summer Shack in Cambridge, Mass. It's designed like a clam shack but with 300 seats.
